citations.narrative:
There were no records of acquisition or record of animals on hand available at the time of the inspection for the 5
peacocks, 33 chickens, and the 10 birds housed in the Education Building.
Per this Section, exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the details of the acquisition and
disposition of animals in their possession to account for the sources of the animals and any animal transfers. The
Licensee needs to prepare records of acquisition and a record of animals on hand for these birds and ensure that the
animal records are kept current for all future animal acquisitions. Correct by 10/14/24.

The outdoor pen housing 2 goats has a 3-sided wooden shelter. It was noted that at least 5 of the horizontal boards
closest to the ground of the left wall of the shelter at the entrance of the shelter were damaged due to areas of missing
and/or deteriorated wood.
Per this Section, outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair. The
Licensee needs to make repairs to the wall of the shelter to maintain the shelter in good repair.

The Ruby Macaw enclosure had a section of small wire mesh located on the inner surface of one wall near the feeding
station. Portions of the wire mesh had been damaged by the macaw so that there were sharp points of wire mesh inside
the enclosure. In addition, there were some wooden trim pieces located on the walls of the enclosure that had been
chewed on by the macaw so that portions of the wooden board were missing. As a result, the sharp points of at least 1
screw and 2 nails were now exposed and accessible to the bird.
Per this Section, primary enclosures must be kept in good repair and have no sharp points or edges that could injure the
birds. The Licensee needs to address the sharp points from the exposed screw/nails and broken wire mesh in the ruby
macaw enclosure to maintain the enclosure in good repair and to protect the bird from injury. Correct by 9/27/24.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Although the birds at the facility were socially housed when appropriate for the species of bird, and were provided with
materials to enhance their environment, a written plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-
being of the birds had not been developed/approved by the Attending Veterinarian and was not available for review at the
time of the inspection.
Per this Section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement
to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian and must be in
accordance with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference
guides. At a minimum, the plan must address each of the following: social grouping, environmental enrichment, special
considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. The Licensee needs to develop an environmental enrichment plan
appropriate for the species of birds maintained and the plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by
10/14/24.
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility representatives.
*END OF REPORT*
